sections.heading: 6.3 Upper and Lower Probabilities
sections.text: Another approach was to treat Bel and Pl as lower and higher probabilities [4]. This approach is of limited use, since not every set of lower and higher probabilities leads to Bel / Pl functions [12], thereby establishing a unidirectional relationship between probability theory and DS theory. According to our interpretation, the Bel / Pl functional pair can be regarded as a kind of interval approximation to some "intrinsic" probability distributions, which, however, cannot be accessed by practicable measurements and which are of interest only as a kind of qualitative explanation for the physical quantities actually measured. Therefore, another approach was to treat them as lower / upper envelopes of a certain probability density functionality [12], [8].

sections.heading: 6.4 Inner and Outer Measures
sections.text: Another approach was to treat Bels / Pl in probability structures and not in probability spaces [7]. Here, the DS rule could be justified as one of the possible outcomes of independent combinations, but no stronger properties were available. This is due to the already mentioned fact that the exclusion of empty intersections actually makes most conceivable processes dependent. Please note that according to our interpretation no such ambiguity occurs, because we not only drop empty overlapping objects, but also re-relativize the remaining ones, so that any subsequently calculated probability does not apply to the original population. Therefore, an attempt was made to drop the DS rule in the probability structures as a whole, but then it was not possible to find a meaningful rule for multi-level thinking [10]. This is a very important negative result. As the DempsterShafer theory is solid in this respect and has many useful properties (as mentioned in the introduction), it should be searched for an interpretation that corresponds to the presumed probability system, rather than an omaxial interpretation of the DS.

sections.heading: 6.5 Rough Set Approach
sections.text: An interesting alternative interpretation of the Dempster-Shafer theory has been found within the framework of rough set theory, whereas we could assume that rough set theory has two different approaches. [24] Essentially, rough set theory is looking for an approximation of the value of a decision that can only be defined by another (explanatory) approach. It usually happens that these attributes are only able to provide a lower and upper approximation of the value of the decision attribute (that is, the set of vectors of explanatory attributes that support only this value of decision variables and the set of explanatory attributes of decision variables. [24] For details see texts by Skowron [24] and Grzyma la-Busse [9]). The Dempster rule of combination is interpreted by Skowron [25] as a combination of opinions of independent experts who may consider different explanatory approaches.

sections.heading: 6.6 General Remarks
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: According to Smets [26], there has so far been no adequate frequentistic interpretation of the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence. • In this paper, a novel frequentistic interpretation of the Dempster-Shafer theory has been found that allows for a close correspondence between belief and plausibility functions and the real data. • This interpretation fits fully within the framework of the Bel / Pl definitions and the Dempster rule of combining independent evidence that relates to this rule for the first time in DST history. • It is distinguished by the fact that the moment of measuring object properties lies behind the combination of evidence that even leads to the abandonment of some costly measurements altogether.
